Award.AwardTitle: Illinois LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate at the University of Illinois at Chicago (2015-2017)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and quality of STEM graduate students from underrepresented populations, with emphasis on Ph.D. matriculation and completion. For the U.S. to remain globally competitive, it is vital that it taps into the talent of all its citizens and provides exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy. BD programs implemented in the nation's institutions of higher education contribute to addressing one of the objectives in NSF's 2014-2018 Strategic Plan, namely to "integrate education and research to support development of a diverse STEM workforce with cutting-edge capabilities." The Illinois Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (ILSAMP) is led by Chicago State University, which is a Predominantly Black University and will host the 2015-2017 cohort of BD Fellows, with the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) as the main implementation campus. UIC will offer a comprehensive program that includes rigorous academic preparation and research training experiences as well as mentorship and professional development activities. Since the strategies implemented at UIC will result in the production of well-trained, highly-skilled STEM Professionals from underrepresented groups, the project will contribute significantly to increasing the diversity and representation in academia and the STEM workforce, thereby ensuring the nation's global competitiveness.

Since starting in 2006, the ILSAMP BD at UIC has produced 22 STEM PhDs out of its 42 fellows from three cohorts. The Illinois LSAMP BD Program at UIC will continue to produce more STEM PhDs following the four primary objectives of the program:
1. To recruit twelve highly motivated students from LSAMP campuses across the nation;
2. To prepare matriculating BD Fellows to study and train towards the PhD;
3. To facilitate activities that will encourage BD Fellows to persist in PhD studies; and
4. To implement a series of activities designed to enhance the education and training of ILSAMP BD Fellows and help them transition to postdoctoral fellowships, placement in the academy, or other positions requiring doctoral level STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Illinois LSAMP: The Illinois Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (ILSAMP) comprises of nine four-year institutions and four two-year colleges. Chicago State University (CSU) is the lead institution for the Illinois LSAMP program. Through very strategic programming, the ILSAMP has successfully increased the number of underrepresented minority students graduating in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics). Some of the graduates either join the STEM workforce or matriculate into graduate STEM programs.  Through the NSF Directorate for Education and Human Resources, the ILSAMP has supported five Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) cohorts at UIC in an effort to increase the number of underrepresented minorities earning terminal (Ph.D.) degrees. The first cohort of pre-doctoral fellows who matriculated in 2006 began to produce positive outcomes in 2011 with the completion of Ph.Ds. in STEM. To date, a total of 64 students, 100% of whom matriculated into the doctoral programs, have been supported by the ILSAMP BD activity at UIC. Twenty-two are currently enrolled, while 29 of them (all minorities) have completed Ph.D. degrees. Thus, the addition of the LSAMP BD initiative has expanded the potential of the Illinois Alliance to address the opposite end of the service spectrum and the opportunity to complete the education cycle with a terminal degree.  As a result of the maturation process, the Alliance has developed and implemented a comprehensive network of programming and support system for URM college students through to the completion of the Ph.D. STEM degree and career in the academia or industry.

Intellectual Merits: The ILSAMP BD at UIC activities were designed to accomplish the central goal of increasing the number of underrepresented persons earning a terminal (Ph.D.) degree in STEM.  Thus, the 2015-2017 cohorts upon the completion of their degrees will foster diversity and broaden the participation of minorities in STEM, similar to the 29 fellows with earned Ph.D. degrees from 17 different STEM disciplines sourced from 19 different LSAMP alliances nationwide. We approached this overarching goal by rolling out a suite of programs that enable graduates to function at the highest levels of competency and professionalism. The programming suites include advanced transitional programs, staff and faculty mentoring, research lab rotations, research projects and professional interactions along with intensive evaluation protocol so as to ensure the completion of the Ph.D. program. Upon the completion of the Ph.D. program, the ten 2015-2017 BD cohort will be prepared for STEM careers in the academia or industry. Nine of the10 fellows for the 2015-2017 BD cohort are still currently enrolled in the Ph.D. program, and thus retention remains at 90%. It may be worth noting that only 2 of the 64 BD fellows have separated from their academic programs due to lack of academic progress. Overall, the ILSAMP BD at UIC retention rate is 96.8%. Thus, the ILSAMP BD postures as a best practice model for the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate initiative.

Broader Impacts: The ILSAMP BD at UIC activity broadened the participation of underrepresented individuals in STEM and related careers before, during, and after the STEM Ph.D. academic experience.   The UIC BD program has played a significant role in doubling the number of STEM Ph.Ds earned by underrepresented minority at UIC since 2011. The 29 fellows who have earned their Ph.D. degrees cut across several disciplines in STEM which include, Civil & Materials Engineering, Mathematics & Computer Science, Civil and Materials Engineering, Biochemistry & Molecular Genetics, Neuroscience, Physiology & Biophysics, Anatomy & Cell Biology, Biological Sciences, Earth & Environmental Sciences, Chemistry, Bioengineering, Pathology, Microbiology & Immunology, Microbiology & Immunology, and Pharmacology, Medicinal Chemistry & Pharmacognosy. The 2015-17 cohort included LSAMP scholars from five different alliances; Florida-Georgia, Illinois, Kansas, Ohio, and Puerto Rico.  UIC's designations as a Minority Serving Institution (MSI) and Hispanic Serving Institution (HIS), and the depth and breadth of the University's academic resources and support programming articulate the University's commitment to diversity in higher education (https://diversity.uic.edu/). Program successes and methods were widely disseminated to the National Science Foundation, institutions, and individuals through print and social media, at professional and research conferences, and recruitment venues. The sharing of information is intended to inform the literature and to encourage the development and implementation of similar programming and thus change the negative perceptions and stereotypes often associated with STEM higher education and STEM workforce.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2018
Modified by: Christopher Botanga

The sharing of information is intended to inform the literature and to encourage the development and implementation of similar programming and thus change the negative perceptions and stereotypes often associated with STEM higher education and STEM workforce.
